result.execSummary:
The defendant Thurmon A Williams was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Costs to be paid at a rate of $25.00 per month commencing 12/15/2016 along with payment plan fee of $15.00. Alternate 8 days jail.

Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.

Case 16CM1774 was dismissed and read into 15CF984.

Defendant Thurmon A Williams in court, in custody, with attorney Samuel W. Benedict.   Kevin Michael Osborne appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant enters a guilty plea as to count 3. Counts 1 and 2 are dismissed and read-in. Court imposed the following sentence:

5 days jail with 5 days credit for time served.
DNA Surcharge $200.00
Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
Pay $25.00 a month comm. 12/15/2016 and every month thereafter or alternate of 8 days jail

Testimony deemed closed.  State moves to bind over.  Defense objects to bind over.  Court finds probable cause to believe that a felony was committed and binds the defendant over for trial.
